content.description:
Climb right of the bolts on the right side of the wall, just hugging the arete but not using it.

Difficult climbing down low so be sure your belayer is attentive.

Watch out for that tree stump...

Climb the rope line on the right side of the North face, clipping 7 bolts as you go.

The tough stuff is down low.  It may be worth a stick clip
No obvious crux, but the climbing is consistently enjoyable and the protection is surprisingly good.
content.protection:
A couple bolts, several railroad spikes (some with an eyelet which can be threaded with a skinny sling) and a light rack. Bolted anchors on top.

This route can be top-roped, but you'll need to set your anchors at the middle of the wall to minimize the swing factor. Also make sure you're not going to collide with an adjacent climber.
content.location: Begin at the bottom left corner of the North Face (at the start of It Doesn't!) and climb diagonally up to the top right corner of the wall.

content.description:
Climb the rope line on the left side of the North face, placing gear and clipping 3 bolts along the way. Mixed.

The route was given the current name as a placeholder for a lack thereof by the first ascensionist.
Climb the left-most side of the North face, just next to the NE arete, but not using it.

Middle of the north face.  Pay attention at the start since it's at grade to get to the first spot to place pro. That being said, it's arguably the best-protected trad line at the trestle.

Shoulder-length runners are useful if you plan on using any of the weird protection on the route (take a look, it's weird).
content.protection: Light rack.  There is odd-looking protection the whole way up, but all of it can and probably should be backed up. Bolted rim anchors.

content.description: No obvious crux, but the upper section is a bit gritty and vegetated, which can make the climbing feel a little sketchy.
content.protection: A bolt, a piton, several railroad spikes (some with an eyelet which can be threaded with a skinny sling) and a light rack. Bolted chain anchors. Bring some long slings. This route can be top-roped, but you'll need to set your anchors at the middle of the wall to minimize the swing factor. Also make sure you're not going to collide with an adjacent climber.
content.location: Begin at the bottom right corner of the North Face (at the start of What Is Jeff?) and climb diagonally up to the top left corner of the wall.
